name: Tenmusu (Tempura Shrimp Rice Ball)
description: Tenmusu is crispy shrimp tempura tucked in a rice ball and wrapped with nori seaweed. This delicious Nagoya specialty is now found throughout Japan in convenience stores and bento shops. Make it fresh at home for a fun lunch or snack!

video.name: How To Make Tenmusu (Recipe) Â§©„ÇÄ„Åô„ÅÆ‰Ωú„ÇäÊñπÔºà„É¨„Ç∑„ÉîÔºâ
video.description:
Tenmusu is a delicious Nagoya specialty food with deep fried shrimp tempura inside a rice ball and wrapped with Nori.  It's easy to make and amazingly yummy!

RICE PLAYLIST ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/RicePlaylist

PRINT RECIPE ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/Tenmusu

Prep tim: 40 minutes
Cook time: 20 minutes
Serves: 12 Tenmusu

Ingredients:

2 rice cooker cups (360 ml) uncooked Japanese short grain rice
Water (for cooking rice, follow instructions for the rice cooker)
Shrimp Tempura, recipe follows
2 Tbsp. mentsuyu (noodle soup base ‚Äì Homemade recipe: https://youtu.be/cGbKa3_pzRk)
Water (for your hands)
Kosher salt (for your hands)
3 sheets nori (seaweed)

Shrimp Tempura

12 medium shrimp
1 Tbsp. potato/corn starch for cleaning shrimp
2 cups neutral flavored oil (vegetable, canola, etc.) for deep frying
¬Ω cup (65 g) cake flour
1 Tbsp. (12 g) potato/corn starch
‚Öì cup (80 ml) ice water
1 Tbsp. rice vinegar
¬Ω Tbsp. sake

Instructions with step-by-step pics ‚ñ∂ http://bit.ly/Tenmusu

recipeIngredient: 1¬Ω cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice
Diamond Crystal kosher salt ((for your hands))
1 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch ((for cleaning the shrimp))

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. For the steamed rice, please note that 1¬Ω cups (2 rice cooker cups, 300 g) of uncooked Japanese short-grain rice yield 4‚Öì cups (660 g) of cooked white rice. See how to cook Japanese rice with a¬†rice cooker,¬†pot over the stove,¬†Instant Pot, or¬†donabe. For this recipe, cook 1¬Ω cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice in 1‚Öî cups water. While the rice is cooking, prepare the shrimp tempura.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. For the steamed rice, please note that 1¬Ω cups (2 rice cooker cups, 300 g) of uncooked Japanese short-grain rice yield 4‚Öì cups (660 g) of cooked white rice. See how to cook Japanese rice with a¬†rice cooker,¬†pot over the stove,¬†Instant Pot, or¬†donabe. For this recipe, cook 1¬Ω cups uncooked Japanese short-grain white rice in 1‚Öî cups water. While the rice is cooking, prepare the shrimp tempura.

itemListElement.text: Peel off the shells (easy to start from the 3rd segment) and tails of 12 medium shrimp. Using a skewer, devein the shrimp. The black vein that runs along the back of the shrimp is the intestinal tract.
itemListElement.name: Peel off the shells (easy to start from the 3rd segment) and tails of 12 medium shrimp. Using a skewer, devein the shrimp. The black vein that runs along the back of the shrimp is the intestinal tract.

itemListElement.text: Place the shrimp in a bowl and add 1 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch and a little bit of water. Rub the shrimp with your hands. This is a pretty common trick in Japan, which helps shrimp become more plump and delicious.
itemListElement.name: Place the shrimp in a bowl and add 1 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch and a little bit of water. Rub the shrimp with your hands. This is a pretty common trick in Japan, which helps shrimp become more plump and delicious.

itemListElement.text: Discard the dirty water and rinse the shrimp a couple of times under cold running water. Drain well and pat dry with a paper towel.
itemListElement.name: Discard the dirty water and rinse the shrimp a couple of times under cold running water. Drain well and pat dry with a paper towel.

itemListElement.text: Heat 2 cups neutral oil to 340‚Äì350¬∫F (170‚Äì180¬∫C). If you make 12 shrimp, 2 cups of oil is a good amount for deep-frying; however, use a smaller pot so that oil is deep enough.
itemListElement.name: Heat 2 cups neutral oil to 340‚Äì350¬∫F (170‚Äì180¬∫C). If you make 12 shrimp, 2 cups of oil is a good amount for deep-frying; however, use a smaller pot so that oil is deep enough.

itemListElement.text: Sift ¬Ω cup cake flour and 1 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch with a fine mesh strainer. This will help the tempura batter become light and crispy.
itemListElement.name: Sift ¬Ω cup cake flour and 1 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch with a fine mesh strainer. This will help the tempura batter become light and crispy.

itemListElement.text: Add ‚Öì cup ice water, 1 Tbsp rice vinegar (unseasoned), and ¬Ω Tbsp sake to the flour. We add the vinegar and sake are added to create a crispier batter.
itemListElement.name: Add ‚Öì cup ice water, 1 Tbsp rice vinegar (unseasoned), and ¬Ω Tbsp sake to the flour. We add the vinegar and sake are added to create a crispier batter.

itemListElement.text: Mix the batter but do not overmix. It‚Äôs okay to leave some lumps in the batter and the consistency should be thick like the batter for fritters. If the batter is too thick, add 1 Tbsp of ice water at a time. Keep the batter cold at all times.
itemListElement.name: Mix the batter but do not overmix. It‚Äôs okay to leave some lumps in the batter and the consistency should be thick like the batter for fritters. If the batter is too thick, add 1 Tbsp of ice water at a time. Keep the batter cold at all times.

itemListElement.text: By now the oil should be close to 340‚Äì350¬∫F (170‚Äì180¬∫C). You can check the temperature with a thermometer or a chopstick. When you see small bubbles around the chopstick, the oil is ready for deep-frying. Tip: If you‚Äòre new to deep-frying, please see my post on how to deep-fry food at home.
itemListElement.name: By now the oil should be close to 340‚Äì350¬∫F (170‚Äì180¬∫C). You can check the temperature with a thermometer or a chopstick. When you see small bubbles around the chopstick, the oil is ready for deep-frying. Tip: If you‚Äòre new to deep-frying, please see my post on how to deep-fry food at home.

itemListElement.text: Coat the shrimp with the batter and deep-fry until golden brown, about 2 minutes for medium-sized shrimp. Do not crowd the pot.
itemListElement.name: Coat the shrimp with the batter and deep-fry until golden brown, about 2 minutes for medium-sized shrimp. Do not crowd the pot.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the cooked shrimp to a wired rack or a plate lined with paper towels to drain the excess oil. Between batches, scoop up the crumbs in the oil as they will burn and turn the oil darker if left in the pot. Continue deep-frying the rest of the shrimp.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the cooked shrimp to a wired rack or a plate lined with paper towels to drain the excess oil. Between batches, scoop up the crumbs in the oil as they will burn and turn the oil darker if left in the pot. Continue deep-frying the rest of the shrimp.

itemListElement.text: Prepare a bowl with 2 Tbsp mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base). Dip both sides of shrimp in the mentsuyu and place back on the wire rack.
itemListElement.name: Prepare a bowl with 2 Tbsp mentsuyu (concentrated noodle soup base). Dip both sides of shrimp in the mentsuyu and place back on the wire rack.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the hot cooked rice into a large bowl to cool down a bit. The rice needs to be warm (cool enough that you can touch it) when you make rice balls. Tip: If you‚Äòd like to review my detailed instructions with step-by-step photos on how to shape rice balls, please see my Onigiri post.
itemListElement.name: Transfer the hot cooked rice into a large bowl to cool down a bit. The rice needs to be warm (cool enough that you can touch it) when you make rice balls. Tip: If you‚Äòd like to review my detailed instructions with step-by-step photos on how to shape rice balls, please see my Onigiri post.

itemListElement.text: Prepare a small bowl of water and a small plate of Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Wet your hands in water and rub some salt on your hands (this is not just for the taste, but also to preserve the rice balls at room temperature).
itemListElement.name: Prepare a small bowl of water and a small plate of Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Wet your hands in water and rub some salt on your hands (this is not just for the taste, but also to preserve the rice balls at room temperature).

itemListElement.text: Scoop about 1 rice paddle of cooked rice into your hand.
itemListElement.name: Scoop about 1 rice paddle of cooked rice into your hand.

itemListElement.text: Make a small well in the center of the rice. In the well, place one piece of your 12 pieces Shrimp Tempura. I like my shrimp tail facing down, but you can show the tail side up if you like.
itemListElement.name: Make a small well in the center of the rice. In the well, place one piece of your 12 pieces Shrimp Tempura. I like my shrimp tail facing down, but you can show the tail side up if you like.

itemListElement.text: Give one quick gentle squeeze to hold everything in one ball, just like how you make a snowball.
itemListElement.name: Give one quick gentle squeeze to hold everything in one ball, just like how you make a snowball.

itemListElement.text: Shape the rice ball into a triangle shape. Make a ‚Äútriangle roof‚Äù with your right hand to create 3 corners of the rice ball. Gently press the rice ball with fingers and the heel of your hands. Never squeeze too tight.
itemListElement.name: Shape the rice ball into a triangle shape. Make a ‚Äútriangle roof‚Äù with your right hand to create 3 corners of the rice ball. Gently press the rice ball with fingers and the heel of your hands. Never squeeze too tight.

itemListElement.text: Cut each of the 3 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) into 4 strips. The rough side should be facing up when you put the rice ball on top (the nice shiny side of the nori is facing outside).
itemListElement.name: Cut each of the 3 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) into 4 strips. The rough side should be facing up when you put the rice ball on top (the nice shiny side of the nori is facing outside).

itemListElement.text: Wrap both sides of the nori toward the center and bend at the bottom. It looks like the rice ball is wearing a kimono (or v-neck shirt).
itemListElement.name: Wrap both sides of the nori toward the center and bend at the bottom. It looks like the rice ball is wearing a kimono (or v-neck shirt).

recipeInstructions.name: To Make the Tenmusu with Plastic Wrap (optional)

itemListElement.text: Now, if you absolutely don‚Äôt want to shape your rice balls with your hands, place a sheet of plastic wrap over a small bowl, big enough so you can pull it out later. Put some rice on top and sprinkle with salt.
itemListElement.name: Now, if you absolutely don‚Äôt want to shape your rice balls with your hands, place a sheet of plastic wrap over a small bowl, big enough so you can pull it out later. Put some rice on top and sprinkle with salt.

itemListElement.text: Make a well in the center and place one shrimp tempura inside. Pull the plastic wrap from all sides.
itemListElement.name: Make a well in the center and place one shrimp tempura inside. Pull the plastic wrap from all sides.

itemListElement.text: Start shaping the rice ball into a triangle shape, the same way as I described above. Unwrap the plastic wrap and put the nori around.
itemListElement.name: Start shaping the rice ball into a triangle shape, the same way as I described above. Unwrap the plastic wrap and put the nori around.

itemListElement.text: If you prefer crispy nori and don‚Äôt plan on eating right away, you can keep the nori in an airtight bag and wrap around the rice when you‚Äôre ready to eat. Enjoy in several hours.
itemListElement.name: If you prefer crispy nori and don‚Äôt plan on eating right away, you can keep the nori in an airtight bag and wrap around the rice when you‚Äôre ready to eat. Enjoy in several hours.

itemListElement.text: It‚Äòs best to enjoy the Tenmusu right away, or within a few hours. Rice gets hard and dry when it is refrigerated (although this works great for fried rice), so my only recommendation is to wrap it with plastic and then a thick kitchen towel to prevent it from becoming dry and hard.
itemListElement.name: It‚Äòs best to enjoy the Tenmusu right away, or within a few hours. Rice gets hard and dry when it is refrigerated (although this works great for fried rice), so my only recommendation is to wrap it with plastic and then a thick kitchen towel to prevent it from becoming dry and hard.
